revision.text:
{{confusing|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}}{{Abortion in the Catholic Church}}In 2009, a nine-year-old Brazilian girl became pregnant with twins. The girl's mother obtained an [[abortion]] for the girl and, afterward, Archbishop [[José Cardoso Sobrinho|José Sobrinho]] said that automatic [[excommunication]] applied to the girl's mother and to the doctors who performed the abortion, prompting national and international criticism. In response, the [[National Conference of Bishops of Brazil]] declared that no one was excommunicated in the case, and in an article published on ''[[L'Osservatore Romano]]'' a Vatican bioethicist rebuked the archbishop for his public statement.
==Law== ;Civil law [[Abortion in Brazil|Abortion is legal under Brazilian law]] in cases of [[Pregnancy from rape|pregnancies resulting from rape]] or in which giving birth would [[Maternal death|endanger the mother's life]].<ref name=reuters>{{cite news |last=Grudgings |first=Stuart|title=Brazil attacks church opposition to girl's abortion|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/03/05/us-brazil-abortion-idUSTRE5247DU20090305|accessdate=13 February 2014|newspaper=Reuters|date=5 March 2009}}</ref><ref name=BBC1>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7926694.stm |publisher=BBC |first=Gary |last=Duffy |title=Rape row sparks excommunications |date=5 March 2009}}</ref><ref name=Brazil2>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2009/03/07/catholic-abortion.html|title=Vatican backs excommunication of Brazilian MDs over child's abortion|date=7 March 2008|publisher=CBC News|accessdate=7 March 2009}}</ref> ;Canon law The [[1983 Code of Canon Law|Code of Canon Law]] says that automatic excommunication is imposed on "a person who procures a completed abortion" ([[Canon 1398]]), but not if, for instance, the act was done "by a person who was coerced by grave fear, even if only relatively grave, or due to necessity or grave inconvenience unless the act is intrinsically evil or tends to the harm of souls".<ref>[http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG1104/__P4W.HTM Code of Canon Law, canon 1323 §4]</ref>
==The abortion== Doctors in [[Recife]] performed an abortion on a nine-year-old girl on 4 March. They judged her life to be at risk because of her age and because she was pregnant with twins and weighed 80 pounds. According to Fatima Maia, the director of the hospital CISAM, if the pregnancy continued, the child could suffer a [[uterine rupture|ruptured uterus]] and [[gynecologic hemorrhage|hemorrhage]], and she also ran the risk of [[diabetes]], [[hypertension]], [[eclampsia]] and [[infertility|lifelong sterility]].<ref>[http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/geral,equipe-medica-excomungada-diz-que-nao-esta-arrependida,334543,0.htm “Equipe médica excomungada diz que não está arrependida”Estadão, 06 March 2009]</ref> She had allegedly been raped by her stepfather.<ref>[http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1883598,00.html Nine-Year-Old's Abortion Outrages Brazil's Catholic Church], ''Time'', Mar. 06, 2009</ref>
== Sobrinho's view and actions == As well as expressly denying that he had excommunicated anyone, but had only said that excommunication had been automatically incurred,<ref>[https://expresso.sapo.pt/menina-violada-abortou-e-a-mae-foi-excomungada-toda-a-polemica=f502990 ''Expresso'',"Menina violada abortou e a mãe foi excomungada: Toda a polémica", 14 March 2009]</ref><ref>[http://noticias.cancaonova.com/bispo-esclarece-que-aborto-e-causa-de-excomunhao-automatica/ "Bispo esclarece que aborto é causa de excomunhão automática" (interview granted to ''Canção Nova''", 5 March 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.rainhamaria.com.br/Pagina/6529/Arcebispo-nao-dei-excomunhao-a-lei-da-Igreja-pune-quem-faz-aborto/imprimir=true "Arcebispo: não dei excomunhão; a lei da Igreja pune quem faz aborto" (interview granted to ''Terra Magazine''}]</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.quadrante.com.br/artigos_detalhes.asp?id=289&cat=4&pagina=1 |title=Francisco Faus, "A menina, o aborto e a excomunhão" |access-date=16 February 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222141248/http://www.quadrante.com.br/artigos_detalhes.asp?id=289&cat=4&pagina=1 |archive-date=22 February 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Sobrinho said that "the law of God is higher than any human laws. When a human law—that is, a law enacted by human legislators—is against the law of God, that law has no value. The adults who approved, who carried out this abortion have incurred excommunication."<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2009/03/05/brazil-church-excommunicates-mom-doctors-after-raped-year-old-has-abortion/ |agency=AP |date=5 March 2009|title=Brazil Church Excommunicates Mom, Doctors After Raped 9-Year-Old Has Abortion |accessdate= 13 February 2014}}</ref> In an interview, he added: "They took the life of an innocent. Abortion is much more serious than killing an adult. An adult may or may not be an innocent, but an unborn child is most definitely innocent. Taking that life cannot be ignored."<ref name="time">{{Cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1883598,00.html |title=Nine-Year-Old's Abortion Outrages Brazil's Catholic Church |first=Andrew |last=Downie |date=6 March 2009|newspaper=Time}}</ref> Sobrinho explained that the rapist stepfather was not excommunicated because abortion, the taking of an innocent life, is even worse than rape. The girl was not excommunicated, because minors are exempt from excommunication.<ref name="cnn">{{Cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/americas/03/11/brazil.rape.abortion/ |publisher=CNN |title=Excommunicated doctor hailed for abortion on child rape victim |date=11 March 2009}}</ref> Archbishop Sobrinho and his diocese also tried to prevent the abortion by approaching the child's parents, the State Governor and the hospital where she was first admitted, after which it put off the abortion indefinitely. His lawyers then issued legal threats against the second hospital where the abortion finally took place. <ref>Muriel Fraser, [http://digital.graphcompubs.com/publication/?i=198105&p=44 "An Abortion in Brazil: The Case That Saved a Life and Divided the Vatican"], Conscience XXXV - No.1, 2014 - Catholics for Choice </ref>{{better source|date=March 2015}}
== Government reaction == President [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]], a Catholic, criticized what he called the "conservative attitude" of the Archbishop in a case where the doctors were trying to save the girl's life, adding: "In this case, the medical profession was more right than the Church."<ref name=Brazil2/><ref name="cnn"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Lula 'rues' Church abortion move|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7929712.stm|accessdate=13 February 2014|newspaper=BBC News|date=6 March 2009}}</ref>
Health Minister [[José Gomes Temporão]] described what he called the Catholic Church's position as "extreme, radical and inadequate".<ref name="reuters"/><ref name=BBC1/> Temporão, who had frequently clashed with the Church on questions such as abortion and state distribution of free condoms,<ref name="reuters"/> called on the participants in a national convention on women's health to acknowledge the "brilliant" work done by the medical team who performed the abortion.<ref name="cnn"/><ref name=DP>{{Cite news|url=http://www.old.diariodepernambuco.com.br/vidaurbana/nota.asp?materia=20090309190626 |title=Médico responsável por aborto de menina é aplaudido em Brasília |date=9 March 2009|publisher=Diario de Pernambuco}}</ref>
== Church hierarchy's view == ===National Conference of Bishops of Brazil=== The National Conference of Bishops of Brazil repudiated Sobrinho's initiative.<ref name=ESP>{{Cite news|url=http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/impresso,cnbb-desautoriza-iniciativa-de-bispo,338133,0.htm |title=CNBB desautoriza iniciativa de bispo |first=Luciana |last=Nunes Leal |date=13 March 2009 |work=O Estadão de S.Paulo |accessdate=13 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223153757/http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/impresso%2Ccnbb-desautoriza-iniciativa-de-bispo%2C338133%2C0.htm |archivedate=23 February 2014 |df= }}</ref> At a press conference, Bishop [[Dimas Lara Barbosa]], Secretary General of the Conference, said that the girl's mother was not excommunicated, since she had acted under pressure to save her daughter's life, and that there were no grounds to declare the doctors excommunicated, because (automatic) excommunication depended on each one's degree of awareness and only those who were "aware and contumacious" were excommunicated.<ref name=ESP/><ref name=Globo/> At the press conference, a document on excommunication written by canonist Enrique Pérez Pujol, who stressed that the penalty should not be applied amid a polemic, was distributed to journalists.<ref name=ESP/>
[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mariana|Archbishop Geraldo Lyrio Rocha]], President of the Conference, avoided answering a question whether Sobrinho had acted hastily in saying that automatic excommunication had occurred. He said that "at no time did he want to hurt someone who was already hurting, but only wished to draw attention to the gravity of the deed of abortion in the face of a certain permissiveness regarding the life of the unborn". He said that Sobrinho had excommunicated no one, but had pointed out that abortion entails the possibility of excommunication, which is a measure intended to make not only an individual but the whole Church community take note of the gravity of the deed. As for the rapist, he said that a rapist "is outside of communion" and "in grave [[mortal sin]]", even though rape is not listed among the crimes that give rise to automatic excommunication. He said: "Rape is something so repugnant that the Church does not need to call attention to it. It is punished by the state justice system, which does not punish abortion so much." He said that talk of excommunication seemed to have made people forget the crime of the rapist, who needed to be punished.<ref name=ESP/><ref name=Globo>{{cite news |last= Bresciani|first=Eduardo|title=Para CNBB, ninguém foi excomungado em caso de aborto de menina de 9 anos |url=http://g1.globo.com/Noticias/Brasil/0,,MUL1040654-5598,00-PARA+CNBB+NINGUEM+FOI+EXCOMUNGADO+EM+CASO+DE+ABORTO+DE+MENINA+DE+ANOS.html |accessdate=13 February 2014|newspaper=O Globo |date=12 March 2009}}</ref>
===Rino Fisichella=== The Holy See's non-official newspaper, ''[[L'Osservatore Romano]]'', published a front-page article on 15 March by Archbishop [[Rino Fisichella]], President of the [[Pontifical Academy for Life]], that was highly critical of Sobrinho's action.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Top Vatican ethicist says abortion saved life of nine-year-old rape victim |date=21 April 2009|url=http://www.christiancentury.org/article/2009-04/top-vatican-ethicist-says-abortion-saved-life-nine-year-old-rape-victim|work=The Christian Century |accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref> Fisichella said that excommunication was automatic, so that focusing on it rather than on helping and supporting the child victim showed a lack of compassion that detracted from the credibility of the Church's anti-abortion teaching.<ref name="obrien">{{Cite book |title=The Church and Abortion: A Catholic Dissent |first=George Dennis |last=O'Brien |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VYBUE1ZZNA4C&pg=PA86 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |year=2010}}</ref><ref name="mines">{{Cite news |work=L'Espresso |url=http://chiesa.espresso.repubblica.it/articolo/1337637?eng=y |date=23 March 2009|title=Drifting Mines. In Africa the Condom, in Brazil Abortion}}</ref> After reiterating the church's condemnation of abortion, he wrote that the moral situation was difficult because of the girl's young age and the risk to her life and praised those who "allowed [her] to live and will help [her] to recover hope and trust".<ref name="mines"/> He wrote: "The conscience of the physician finds itself alone when forced to decide the best thing to do. A choice like that of having to save a life, knowing that one puts a second at serious risk, never comes easily."<ref>{{cite news|date=21 March 2009|accessdate=13 February 2014|newspaper=Washington Post|title=Vatican Official Defends Child's Abortion|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/20/AR2009032002415.html |first=Francis X.|last=Rocca}}</ref>
The [[Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith]] responded to press coverage of Fisichella's article calling it manipulation and exploitation. It issued a clarification that the article did not signal a change of doctrine and said that "the Church's teaching on procured abortion has not changed, nor can it change".<ref name="obrien"/><ref name=CDF>[http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/congregations/cfaith/documents/rc_con_cfaith_doc_20090711_aborto-procurato_en.html Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, "Clarification on procured abortion"]</ref><ref>[http://chiesa.espresso.repubblica.it/articolo/1339277?eng=y The Holy Office Teaches Archbishop Fisichella a Lesson]</ref> The clergy of the Archdiocese of Olinda and Recife took issue with Fisichella, stating that the local Church had been supportive of the girl and her mother.<ref name="mines"/> The Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith ruled that Sobrinho had acted "with all pastoral solicitude".<ref name="obrien"/><ref name=CDF/> The members of the Academy gave Fisichella a vote of no confidence because of his article, and he was reassigned in the next year to the [[Pontifical Council for Promoting the New Evangelization]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://ncronline.org/news/vatican/vatican-academy-mulls-how-pro-life-pro-life-enough |first=John L. |last=Allen Jr. |title=Vatican academy mulls how pro-life is pro-life enough |date=30 May 2012|work=National Catholic Reporter}}</ref>
===Others=== Cardinal [[Giovanni Battista Re]], Prefect of the [[Congregation for Bishops]] and President of the [[Pontifical Commission for Latin America]], deplored what he called an attack on the Church in Brazil: "It is a sad case, but the real problem is that the twins conceived were two innocent persons, who had the right to live and could not be eliminated. Life must always be protected. The attack on the Brazilian church is unjustified." He added that excommunication of those who performed the abortion was just.<ref name=Brazil2/>
[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Gap|Bishop Jean-Michel di Falco]] of [[Gap, Hautes-Alpes|Gap, France]], criticized what he saw as the un-Christlike nature of Sobrinho's statement. He said that bishops should act as pastors rather than executioners. As had the National Conference of Bishops of Brazil, he denied the applicability of Canon 1398 of the [[Code of Canon Law]] to the girl's mother, because such an automatic excommunication does not apply to someone who acts out of grave fear.<ref>[http://www.zenit.org/article-20441?l=french Mgr di FALCO, évêque de Gap, sur l'excommunication au Brésil] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316160505/http://www.zenit.org/article-20441?l=french |date=16 March 2012 }}</ref>
== Other reactions == On 9 March 2009, Health Minister [[José Gomes Temporão|Temporão]] interrupted the opening ceremony of a national medical convention on women's health in Brasília in order to compliment Dr. Olímpio Moraes, one of the doctors who carried out the abortion and who was in attendance. Participants gave Moraes a standing ovation.<ref name="cnn"/><ref name=DP/>
Moraes expressed gratitude to Sobrinho for the excommunication, which, he said, had drawn attention to Brazil's restrictive abortion laws. Another of the doctors involved said that he will continue attending [[Mass (Catholic Church)|Mass]], "praying, conversing with God, and asking him to illuminate me and my colleagues in our medical team to help us take care of people in similar cases."<ref name="cnn"/>
The United Nations [[Committee on the Rights of the Child]], in its January 2014 assessment of the [[Concluding observations on the second periodic report of the Holy See|Holy See's compliance]] with the U.N. [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]], cited this Brazil case. It "urge[d] the Holy See to review its position on abortion which places obvious risks on the life and health of pregnant girls and to amend Canon 1398 relating to abortion with a view to identifying circumstances under which access to abortion services can be permitted."<ref>Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights: [http://tbinternet.ohchr.org/_layouts/treatybodyexternal/Download.aspx?symbolno=CRC%2FC%2FVAT%2FCO%2F2&Lang=en Concluding observations on the second periodic report of the Holy See, 31 January 2014], retrieved 8 February 2014</ref>
==See also== *''[[País do Desejo]]'' *[[Catholic Church and abortion]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

[[File:Phytate.svg|thumb|right|[[Phytic acid]] ([[Deprotonation|deprotonated]] phytate [[Ion|anion]] in the picture) is an antinutrient that interferes with the absorption of minerals from the diet.|200x200px]] '''Antinutrients''' are natural or synthetic compounds that interfere with the absorption of [[nutrient]]s.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XpUjsqD7lFUC&pg=PA47|title=Oxford dictionary of biochemistry and molecular biology|last=|first=|date=2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|others=Cammack, Richard|year=|isbn=9780198529170|edition=Rev.|location=Oxford|pages=47|chapter=Aa|doi=10.1093/acref/9780198529170.001.0001|oclc=65467611|chapter-url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780198529170.001.0001/acref-9780198529170-e-1324?rskey=PPEnbe&result=1261}}</ref> Nutrition studies focus on these antinutrients commonly found in food sources and beverages.
== Examples == [[Phytic acid]] has a strong binding affinity to [[Mineral (nutrient)|minerals]] such as [[calcium]], [[magnesium]], [[iron]], [[copper]], and [[zinc]]. This results in precipitation, making the minerals unavailable for absorption in the [[Gastrointestinal tract|intestines]].<ref>{{cite journal | first1 = Päivi | last1 = Ekholm | first2 = Liisa | last2 = Virkki | first3 = Maija | last3 = Ylinen | first4 = Liisa | last4 = Johansson | name-list-format = vanc |title=The effect of phytic acid and some natural chelating agents on the solubility of mineral elements in oat bran |journal=Food Chemistry |date=Feb 2003 |volume=80 |issue=2 |pages=165–70 |doi=10.1016/S0308-8146(02)00249-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cheryan M | title = Phytic acid interactions in food systems | journal = Critical Reviews in Food Science and Nutrition | volume = 13 | issue = 4 | pages = 297–335 | year = 1980 | pmid = 7002470 | doi = 10.1080/10408398009527293 }}</ref> Phytic acids are common in the hulls of nuts, seeds and grains and of great importance in [[agriculture]] animal nutrition and [[eutrophication]] wise due to the mineral [[chelation]] and bound [[phosphate]]s released in to the environment. Without the need to use phytate (but also nutrient) reducing [[Mill (grinding)|milling]],<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Bohn L, Meyer AS, Rasmussen SK | title = Phytate: impact on environment and human nutrition. A challenge for molecular breeding | journal = Journal of Zhejiang University. Science. B | volume = 9 | issue = 3 | pages = 165–91 | date = March 2008 | pmid = 18357620 | pmc = 2266880 | doi = 10.1631/jzus.B0710640 }}</ref> the amount of phytic acid is commonly reduced in [[animal feed]]s by adding [[Phytase#Histidine acid phosphatases (HAPs)|histidine acid phosphate]] type of [[phytase]]s to them.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kumar V, Singh G, Verma AK, Agrawal S | title = In silico characterization of histidine Acid phytase sequences | journal = Enzyme Research | volume = 2012 | pages = 845465 | date = 2012 | pmid = 23304454 | pmc = 3523131 | doi = 10.1155/2012/845465 }}</ref>
[[Protease]] [[enzyme inhibitor|inhibitors]] are substances that inhibit the actions of [[trypsin]], [[pepsin]] and other proteases in the gut, preventing the digestion and subsequent absorption of protein. For example, [[Bowman–Birk protease inhibitor|Bowman–Birk trypsin inhibitor]] is found in soybeans.<ref>{{cite journal | first1 = Anna L. | last1 = Tan-Wilson | first2 = Jean C. | last2 = Chen | first3 = Michele C. | last3 = Duggan | first4 = Cathy | last4 = Chapman | first5 = R. Scott | last5 = Obach | first6 = Karl A. | last6 = Wilson | name-list-format = vanc |title=Soybean Bowman-Birk trypsin isoinhibitors: classification and report of a glycine-rich trypsin inhibitor class |journal=J. Agric. Food Chem. |year=1987 |volume=35 |issue=6 |page=974 |doi=10.1021/jf00078a028}}</ref>
[[Lipase]] inhibitors interfere with enzymes, such as [[human pancreatic lipase]], that catalyze the hydrolysis of some [[lipid]]s, including fats. For example, the anti-obesity drug [[orlistat]] causes a percentage of fat to pass through the digestive tract undigested.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Heck AM, Yanovski JA, Calis KA | title = Orlistat, a new lipase inhibitor for the management of obesity | journal = Pharmacotherapy | volume = 20 | issue = 3 | pages = 270–9 | date = March 2000 | pmid = 10730683 | doi = 10.1592/phco.20.4.270.34882 }}</ref>
[[Amylase]] inhibitors prevent the action of enzymes that break the [[glycosidic bond]]s of [[starch]]es and other complex [[carbohydrate]]s, preventing the release of simple sugars and absorption by the body. [[Amylase]] inhibitors, like lipase inhibitors, have been used as a diet aid and obesity treatment. Amylase inhibitors are present in many types of beans; commercially available amylase inhibitors are extracted from white [[kidney bean]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Preuss HG | title = Bean amylase inhibitor and other carbohydrate absorption blockers: effects on diabesity and general health | journal = Journal of the American College of Nutrition | volume = 28 | issue = 3 | pages = 266–76 | date = June 2009 | pmid = 20150600 | doi = 10.1080/07315724.2009.10719781 }}</ref>
[[Oxalic acid]] and [[oxalate]]s are present in many plants and in significant amounts particularly in [[rhubarb]], [[tea]], [[spinach]], [[parsley]] and [[Portulaca oleracea|purslane]]. Oxalates bind to [[calcium]] and prevent its absorption in the human body.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Dolan LC, Matulka RA, Burdock GA | title = Naturally occurring food toxins | journal = Toxins | volume = 2 | issue = 9 | pages = 2289–332 | date = September 2010 | pmid = 22069686 | pmc = 3153292 | doi = 10.3390/toxins2092289 }}</ref>
[[Glucosinolate]]s prevent the uptake of [[iodine]], affecting the function of the [[thyroid]] and thus are considered [[goitrogen]]s. They are found in plants such as [[broccoli]], [[Brussels sprout|brussel sprouts]], [[cabbage]], [[Brassica juncea|mustard greens]], [[radish]]es and [[cauliflower]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Dolan LC, Matulka RA, Burdock GA | title = Naturally occurring food toxins | journal = Toxins | volume = 2 | issue = 9 | pages = 2289–332 | date = September 2010 | pmid = 22069686 | pmc = 3153292 | doi = 10.3390/toxins2092289 }}</ref>
Excessive intake of required nutrients can also result in them having an anti-nutrient action. Excessive intake of [[dietary fiber]] can reduce the transit time through the intestines to such a degree that other nutrients cannot be absorbed. However, this effect is often not seen in practice and reduction of absorbed minerals can be attributed mainly to the phytic acids in fibrous food.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/other-nutrients/fiber|title=Fiber|last=|first=|date=2014-04-28|work=Linus Pauling Institute|access-date=2018-04-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180414180232/http://lpi.oregonstate.edu/mic/other-nutrients/fiber|archive-date=2018-04-13|dead-url=no|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Coudray C, Demigné C, Rayssiguier Y | title = Effects of dietary fibers on magnesium absorption in animals and humans | journal = The Journal of Nutrition | volume = 133 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–4 | date = January 2003 | pmid = 12514257 | doi = 10.1093/jn/133.1.1 | url = https://academic.oup.com/jn/article/133/1/1/4687577 }}</ref> Foods high in [[Calcium in biology|calcium]] eaten simultaneously with foods containing [[iron]] can decrease the absorption of iron via an unclear mechanism involving iron [[transport protein]] h[[DMT1]], which calcium can inhibit.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Scheers N | title = Regulatory effects of Cu, Zn, and Ca on Fe absorption: the intricate play between nutrient transporters | journal = Nutrients | volume = 5 | issue = 3 | pages = 957–70 | date = March 2013 | pmid = 23519291 | pmc = 3705329 | doi = 10.3390/nu5030957 }}</ref>
Some [[Protein (nutrient)|proteins]] can also be antinutrients, such as the [[trypsin inhibitor]]s and [[lectin]]s found in [[legume]]s. These [[enzyme inhibitor]]s interfere with digestion.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gilani GS, Cockell KA, Sepehr E | title = Effects of antinutritional factors on protein digestibility and amino acid availability in foods | journal = Journal of AOAC International | volume = 88 | issue = 3 | pages = 967–87 | date = May 2005 | pmid = 16001874 }}</ref> [[Avidin]] is an antinutrient found in active form in raw [[egg white]]s. It binds very tightly to [[biotin]] ([[vitamin]] B7)<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Miranda JM, Anton X, Redondo-Valbuena C, Roca-Saavedra P, Rodriguez JA, Lamas A, Franco CM, Cepeda A | title = Egg and egg-derived foods: effects on human health and use as functional foods | journal = Nutrients | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | pages = 706–29 | date = January 2015 | pmid = 25608941 | pmc = 4303863 | doi = 10.3390/nu7010706 }}</ref> and can cause deficiency of B7 in animals<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Poissonnier LA, Simpson SJ, Dussutour A | title = Observations of the "egg white injury" in ants | journal = PLOS One | volume = 9 | issue = 11 | pages = e112801 | date = 2014-11-13 | pmid = 25392989 | pmc = 4231089 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0112801 }}</ref> and, in extreme cases, in humans.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Baugh CM, Malone JH, Butterworth CE | title = Human biotin deficiency. A case history of biotin deficiency induced by raw egg consumption in a cirrhotic patient | journal = The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition | volume = 21 | issue = 2 | pages = 173–82 | date = February 1968 | pmid = 5642891 | doi = 10.1093/ajcn/21.2.173 | url = https://academic.oup.com/ajcn/article-lookup/doi/10.1093/ajcn/21.2.173 }}</ref>
Widespread form of antinutrients are the [[flavonoid]]s, which are a group of [[polyphenol]]ic compounds that include [[tannin]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Beecher GR | title = Overview of dietary flavonoids: nomenclature, occurrence and intake | journal = The Journal of Nutrition | volume = 133 | issue = 10 | pages = 3248S-3254S | date = October 2003 | pmid = 14519822 | doi = 10.1093/jn/133.10.3248S | url = http://jn.nutrition.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=14519822 }}</ref> These compounds [[chelate]] metals such as iron and zinc and reduce the absorption of these nutrients,<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Karamać M | title = Chelation of Cu(II), Zn(II), and Fe(II) by tannin constituents of selected edible nuts | journal = International Journal of Molecular Sciences | volume = 10 | issue = 12 | pages = 5485–97 | date = December 2009 | pmid = 20054482 | pmc = 2802006 | doi = 10.3390/ijms10125485 }}</ref> but they also inhibit digestive enzymes and may also precipitate proteins.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Adamczyk B, Simon J, Kitunen V, Adamczyk S, Smolander A | title = Tannins and Their Complex Interaction with Different Organic Nitrogen Compounds and Enzymes: Old Paradigms versus Recent Advances | journal = ChemistryOpen | volume = 6 | issue = 5 | pages = 610–614 | date = October 2017 | pmid = 29046854 | pmc = 5641916 | doi = 10.1002/open.201700113 }}</ref>
[[Saponin]]s in plants may serve as [[insecticide|anti-feedant]]s<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Moses T, Papadopoulou KK, Osbourn A | title = Metabolic and functional diversity of saponins, biosynthetic intermediates and semi-synthetic derivatives | journal = Critical Reviews in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology | volume = 49 | issue = 6 | pages = 439–62 | date = 2014 | pmid = 25286183 | pmc = 4266039 | doi = 10.3109/10409238.2014.953628 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Sparg SG, Light ME, van Staden J | title = Biological activities and distribution of plant saponins | journal = Journal of Ethnopharmacology | volume = 94 | issue = 2-3 | pages = 219–43 | date = October 2004 | pmid = 15325725 | doi = 10.1016/j.jep.2004.05.016 }}</ref> and can be classified as antinutrients.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Difo VH, Onyike E, Ameh DA, Njoku GC, Ndidi US | title = Changes in nutrient and antinutrient composition of Vigna racemosa flour in open and controlled fermentation | journal = Journal of Food Science and Technology | volume = 52 | issue = 9 | pages = 6043–8 | date = September 2015 | pmid = 26345026 | pmc = 4554638 | doi = 10.1007/s13197-014-1637-7 }}</ref>
== Occurrence == Antinutrients are found at some level in almost all foods for a variety of reasons. However, their levels are reduced in modern crops, probably as an outcome of the process of [[domestication]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Plant Toxins and Antinutrients |author=GEO-PIE Project |publisher=[[Cornell University]] |url=http://www.geo-pie.cornell.edu/issues/toxins.html |deadurl=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612160331/http://www.geo-pie.cornell.edu/issues/toxins.html |archive-date=June 12, 2008 }}</ref> The possibility now exists to eliminate antinutrients entirely using [[genetic engineering]]; but, since these compounds may also have beneficial effects, such genetic modifications could make the foods more nutritious but not improve people's health.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Welch RM, Graham RD | title = Breeding for micronutrients in staple food crops from a human nutrition perspective | journal = Journal of Experimental Botany | volume = 55 | issue = 396 | pages = 353–64 | date = February 2004 | pmid = 14739261 | doi = 10.1093/jxb/erh064 | url = http://jexbot.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=14739261 }}</ref>
Many traditional methods of food preparation such as [[fermentation (food)|fermentation]], [[cooking]], and [[malting]] increase the nutritive quality of plant foods through reducing certain antinutrients such as phytic acid, polyphenols, and oxalic acid.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hotz C, Gibson RS | title = Traditional food-processing and preparation practices to enhance the bioavailability of micronutrients in plant-based diets | journal = The Journal of Nutrition | volume = 137 | issue = 4 | pages = 1097–100 | date = April 2007 | pmid = 17374686 | doi = 10.1093/jn/137.4.1097 | url = http://jn.nutrition.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17374686 }}</ref> Such processing methods are widely used in societies where cereals and legumes form a major part of the diet.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Chavan JK, Kadam SS | title = Nutritional improvement of cereals by fermentation | journal = Critical Reviews in Food Science and Nutrition | volume = 28 | issue = 5 | pages = 349–400 | year = 1989 | pmid = 2692608 | doi = 10.1080/10408398909527507 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Phillips RD | title = Starchy legumes in human nutrition, health and culture | journal = Plant Foods for Human Nutrition | volume = 44 | issue = 3 | pages = 195–211 | date = November 1993 | pmid = 8295859 | doi = 10.1007/BF01088314 }}</ref> An important example of such processing is the fermentation of [[cassava]] to produce cassava flour: this fermentation reduces the levels of both toxins and antinutrients in the tuber.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Oboh G, Oladunmoye MK | title = Biochemical changes in micro-fungi fermented cassava flour produced from low- and medium-cyanide variety of cassava tubers | journal = Nutrition and Health | volume = 18 | issue = 4 | pages = 355–67 | year = 2007 | pmid = 18087867 | doi = 10.1177/026010600701800405 }}</ref>
== See also == * [[Antimetabolite]] * [[Biopesticide]] * [[Plant defense against herbivory]]
== References == {{reflist|32em}}
== Further reading == * {{cite book |author=Shahidi, Fereidoon |title=Antinutrients and phytochemicals in food |publisher=American Chemical Society |location=Columbus, OH |year=1997 |isbn=0-8412-3498-1}}
[[Category:Nutrition]]

The '''Aqueduct of Nottolini''' is a prominent [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical architectural]] landmark near the city of [[Lucca]], region of [[Tuscany]], Italy. The 19th-century structure brought water to Lucca from the mountains south of the city through a stone channel supported by more than 400 arches, stretching for over 3 kilometres. It is now interrupted by the east-west [[autostrada]] [[Autostrada A11 (Italy)|A11]] from [[Florence]] to [[Pisa]]. [[Image:Aquädukt Lorenzo Nottolini 2009-07-21.JPG|thumb|center|800px|Aqueduct]]
==Construction== [[File:Aqueduct Nottolini Guamo Lucca.jpg|thumb|left|Temple cistern of Guamo and first arches]] While the arches of the aqueduct are often confused as being those of an ancient [[Roman aqueduct]], construction of the aqueduct was begun in 1823 by the architect [[Lorenzo Nottolini]], under the rule of [[Maria Luisa of Spain, Duchess of Lucca]], and continued until 1851. In the slopes of Monte di Vorno, a number of springs were conveyed through rocky channels to a domed circular stone temple-cistern ({{coord|43.80755|10.52072|format=dms|type:landmark_region:IT|display=inline|name=Cistern in Guamo}}) located near San Quirico in the frazione of Guamo.
[[Image:Acq nottolini.jpg|thumb|Aqueduct and temple-tank of San Concordio]] The water was then conveyed northward through covered stone conduits to the temple-tank of San Concordio ({{coord|43.83576|10.50879|format=dms|type:landmark_region:IT|display=inline|name=Tank of San Concordio}}), just outside the fortified walls of Lucca. The arches were mainly built with brick.
From the San Concordio tank, potable water was led by metal pipes into fountains in the city, starting with the circular fountain in Piazza Antelminelli next to [[Lucca Cathedral]].<ref>[http://en.capannori-terraditoscana.org/index.php/territory/historical_personages/lorenzo_nottolini.html Terra di Toscana], entry on aqueduct.</ref>
When inaugurated, the flow of water was governed completely by gravity. The final iron conduits allowed for expansion and contraction of the metal.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=cHs5AAAAcAAJ Guida del Forestiere per la citta e il contado di Lucca], by Tommaso Felice Trenta, 1820, page 139-141.</ref> The interruption of the aqueduct occurred when the autostrada was constructed by [[Benito Mussolini]]'s government in 1928–1932.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{coord|43.8218|10.5147|format=dms|type:landmark_region:IT_dim:2000|display=title}} {{GeoGroup}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aqueduct of Nottolini}} [[Category:Aqueducts in Italy|Nottolini Aqueduct]] [[Category:Neoclassical architecture in Tuscany]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Lucca]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.2.5)
revision.text:
{{POV check|date=October 2010}} '''Automatic Generic Substitution''' is a proposal by the [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] (DH) whereby in January 2010 pharmacists could be obliged to substitute a [[generic drug|generic]] version (a version of the drug with the same active ingredient) of a medication even if the prescriber had written the prescription for a specific [[brand]], as part of a new deal on drug pricing.
This is different from generic prescribing. In most cases, receiving a generic medicine is fully appropriate and effective for patient treatment and should continue. Indeed, generic prescribing already accounts for 83% of all prescriptions in the UK.<ref name="Prescribing costs in primary care">{{Cite book|author=National Audit Office |title=Prescribing costs in primary care |url=https://www.nao.org.uk/report/prescribing-costs-in-primary-care/ |location=London |publisher=The Stationery Office |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-10-294517-1}}</ref>
The DH is conducting a public formal consultation on the arrangements for the implementation of Automatic Generic Substitution. The consultation document can be found [http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Consultations/Liveconsultations/DH_110517 here]
Currently, Automatic Generic Substitution is not permitted under UK law, except in an emergency or under strict hospital control.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}}
==Pharmacy dispensing rules==
Under current dispensing rules, the prescriber writes a prescription for a branded or generic medicine, which is dispensed by a [[pharmacist]].
Under the proposed pharmacy dispensing rules, if Automatic Generic Substitution is introduced, the pharmacist may dispense either the prescribed product, or they may replace it with a generic or another brand without being required to inform the patient or healthcare professional.
It has been indicated by the DH that a prescriber will be able to tick a "do not substitute" box to prevent a proprietary medicine being replaced with a generic alternative. A group of people drawn from academia, medicine and patient groups has reported that it may not be adequate to safeguard patients. They state an example of when patients request a repeat prescription that may not be written by their doctor.<ref name="Automatic Generic Substitution - Clinical Implications for Patients">{{Cite web|title=Automatic Generic Substitution - Clinical Implications for Patients |date=June 2009 |url=http://www.kidney.org.uk/main/switch_meds/AutomaticGenericSubstitutionClinicalImplicationsForPatientsJuly09.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101228032056/http://www.kidney.org.uk/main/switch_meds/AutomaticGenericSubstitutionClinicalImplicationsForPatientsJuly09.pdf |archivedate=2010-12-28 |df= }}</ref>
==Variations between generics== Generic medicines have the same [[active ingredient]] as the branded medicine, but are not always identical, which could affect some patients. The amount of drug that finally reaches the site of action is known as the [[bioavailability]], directly impacting on the effectiveness and tolerability of a drug.
For a generic medicine to be considered bioequivalent, the [[European Medicines Agency]] (EMEA) requires that the bioavailability lies between 80% and 125% of the original branded medicine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tga.gov.au/DOCS/pdf/euguide/ewp/140198entga.pdf |publisher=[[European Medicines Agency]] |title=Note for guidance on the investigation of bioavailability and bioequivalence |location=London |year=2000}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emea.europa.eu/pdfs/human/qwp/140198enrev1.pdf |publisher=[[European Medicines Agency]] |title=Guideline on the investigation of bioequivalence |location=London |year=2008 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Patients can be switched between different generic medicines, which can mean that they might receive a generic medicine with effectively 25% more active ingredient than the branded medicine on one occasion and one with effectively 20% less active ingredient on the next.
==Impact on patient adherence== Generic medicines often have different sizes, shapes, colours and packaging to each other, and to the branded medicine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rcplondon.ac.uk/PROFESSIONAL-ISSUES/Pages/Physicians-and-the-Pharmaceutical-Industry.aspx |publisher=[[Royal College of Physicians]] |title=Patients, physicians, the pharmaceutical industry and the NHS |date=February 2009}}</ref> Switching between medications has been shown to significantly reduce [[Compliance (medicine)|adherence]] to treatment.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Thiebaud P, Patel BV, Nichol MB, Berenbeim DM |title=The effect of switching on compliance and persistence: the case of statin treatment |journal=The American Journal of Managed Care |volume=11 |issue=11 |pages=670–4 |date=November 2005 |pmid=16268750 |url=http://www.ajmc.com/pubMed.php?pii=3031}}</ref> Poor adherence is known to be associated with worse outcomes and increased costs for a variety of conditions.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Bainbridge JL, Ruscin JM |title=Challenges of treatment adherence in older patients with Parkinson's disease |journal=Drugs & Aging |volume=26 |issue=2 |pages=145–55 |year=2009 |pmid=19220071 |doi=10.2165/0002512-200926020-00006}}</ref><ref name=pmid18693783>{{Cite journal|author=Ansell BJ |title=Not getting to goal: the clinical costs of noncompliance |journal=Journal of Managed Care Pharmacy |volume=14 |issue=6 Suppl B |pages=9–15 |date=July 2008 |pmid=18693783 |url=http://www.amcp.org/data/jmcp/JMCPSuppB_S9-S15.pdf}}</ref>
These problems are exacerbated in elderly patients, who are more likely to be taking multiple medications.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Carey IM, De Wilde S, Harris T |title=What factors predict potentially inappropriate primary care prescribing in older people? Analysis of UK primary care patient record database |journal=Drugs & Aging |volume=25 |issue=8 |pages=693–706 |year=2008 |pmid=18665661 |doi=10.2165/00002512-200825080-00006|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
It is estimated that £800 million worth of drugs is wasted annually in [[primary care]].<ref name="Prescribing costs in primary care"/> A report from a group of people drawn from academia, medicine and patient groups suggests this could increase further with a reduction in patient adherence due to Automatic Generic Substitution.<ref name="Automatic Generic Substitution - Clinical Implications for Patients"/>
Under Automatic Generic Substitution, a patient could receive a different medication, with a different appearance and [[Dose (biochemistry)|dosage]] instructions, on each visit to the pharmacy.
==Generic prescribing in the UK== There are many cases where generic prescribing is fully appropriate and vital to containing costs. Generic prescribing in the UK is currently at 83%.<ref name="Prescribing costs in primary care"/> The [[Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry ]] (ABPI) suggests that the maximum possible level for generic prescribing would be in the region of 90%,<ref name="PPRS update 10">{{Cite journal|publisher=[[Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry]] |journal=PPRS update |date=March 2009 |issue=10}}</ref> as a number of medicines have either no generic equivalent or are not appropriate for substitution, e.g. [[slow-release]] formulations. Prescribers now commonly prescribe a generic over a brand-name product in cases where it does not present any significant disadvantages to their patients.
==The options for introducing Automatic Generic Substitution== The DH is proposing three options for introducing generic substitution: * Option 1 – do nothing * Option 2 – Introduce generic substitution but with specific medicines excluded * Option 3 – Introduce generic substitution but with specific medicines included
The DH favours Option 3; Introduction of dispensing flexibility but limiting the scheme in such a way that the arrangements only apply to a selected group of products on a select list
The initial inclusion list for Option 3 can be found [http://www.dh.gov.uk/prod_consum_dh/groups/dh_digitalassets/documents/digitalasset/dh_110511.pdf here]
If Option 3 is adopted, the list can be "revised" by DH without any further consultation and may be revised up to four times per year.
A group of people drawn from academia, medicine and patient groups has raised concerns in a report, ‘Automatic Generic Substitution – Clinical Implications for Patients’ that any substitution could be detrimental to the patient. It is known that many medicines have the potential to interact with each other. Medicines on the inclusion list could be substituted for a different version and interact differently with a patient’s established medicine.
This could be a particular issue for the elderly, who often have multiple conditions and receive multiple medications.<ref name="Automatic Generic Substitution - Clinical Implications for Patients"/> A study of patients registered with 201 UK general practices showed that patients aged 65–69 years received [[Medical prescription|repeat prescriptions]] for an average of 5.9 medications in 2005.<ref name=pmid18693783/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.genericsubstitution.com/ Automatic Generic Substitution] * [http://www.abpi.org.uk/ ABPI] * [http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Consultations/Liveconsultations/index.htm/ Department of Health]
[[Category:Department of Health (United Kingdom)]]

revision.text:
[[File:Pickolo - Automatic colony picker add-on for Tecan EVO robot.JPG|thumb|right|Pickolo - an automatic colony picker add-on for a Tecan robot shown in a typical setup. A petri plate is placed on a light table (bottom). The camera (top) is used to photograph the plate and image analysis algorithms used to choose the right colonies to pick. A disposable tip (taken from the rack on the left) is used to touch each colony and transfer it to a collection plate (bottom right). In a fully automatic setup a plate stacker (right) is used to process many plates in a serial manner.]] A '''colony picker''' is an instrument used to automatically identify [[Colony (biology)|microbial colonies]] growing on a [[Agar|solid]] [[Growth medium|media]], pick them and duplicate them either onto solid or liquid media. It is used in research laboratories as well as in industrial environments such as [[Food safety|food testing]] and in [[microbiological culture]]s.
== Uses == In food safety<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsis.usda.gov/PDF/MLG_41_01.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=December 14, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111207095754/http://www.fsis.usda.gov/PDF/MLG_41_01.pdf |archivedate=December 7, 2011 }}</ref> and in clinical diagnosis colony picking is used to isolate individual colonies for identification. Colony pickers automate this procedure, saving costs and personnel and reducing [[human error]]. In the [[drug discovery]] process they are used for [[High throughput screening|screening]] purposes by picking thousands of microbial colonies and transferring them for further testing.<ref>{{cite journal|author=USA |title=Automated panning and screening procedure on microplates for antibody generation from phage display libraries. |date=2015-09-28 |pmid=19224869 |doi=10.1177/1087057108330113 |volume=14 |journal=J Biomol Screen |pages=282–93}}</ref> Other uses include [[cloning]] procedures and [[DNA sequencing]].
== as add-on == Colony pickers are sold either as stand-alone instruments or as add-ons to liquid handling robots, using the robot as the [[actuator]] and adding a camera and [[image analysis]] capabilities. This strategy lowers the price of the system considerably<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-articles/gene-cloning-and-colony-picking/3904/ |title=Gene Cloning and Colony Picking | GEN Magazine Articles | GEN |publisher=Genengnews.com |date= |accessdate=2016-05-19}}</ref> and adds reusability as the robot can still be used for other purposes.
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Biological techniques and tools]] [[Category:Food safety]]

{{For|the Noah Ashenhurst novel|Comfort Food (novel)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} [[File:Chicken noodle soup (cropped).jpg|thumb|250px|[[Chicken soup]], a common classic comfort food that is found across various cultures]]
'''Comfort food''' is [[food]] that provides a [[nostalgic]] or sentimental value to someone,<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/comfort%20food "Comfort Food."] (definition). [http://www.merriam-webster.com Merriam-webster.com]. Accessed July 2011.</ref> and may be characterized by its high [[Calorie|caloric nature]], high [[carbohydrate]] level, or simple [[Food preparation|preparation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Comfort food|url=http://wordnetweb.princeton.edu/perl/webwn?s=comfort+food|publisher=WordNet 3.1|accessdate=10 January 2016}}</ref> The nostalgia may be specific to an individual, or it may apply to a specific [[culture]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Rufus |first=Anneli |title=How comfort foods work like Prozac |url=http://www.salon.com/2011/06/23/comfort_food_psychology/ |publisher=Gilt Taste |date=23 June 2011 |accessdate=8 April 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XeO3Tlsm?url=http://www.salon.com/2011/06/23/comfort_food_psychology/ |archivedate=9 April 2015 |df=dmy }} ()</ref>
==Definition== The term ''comfort food'' has been traced back at least to 1966, when the ''[[Palm Beach Post]]'' used it in a story: "Adults, when under severe emotional stress, turn to what could be called ‘comfort food’—food associated with the security of childhood, like mother’s [[poached egg]] or famous [[chicken soup]]."<ref name="theatlantic">{{cite web | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2015/04/why-comfort-food-comforts/389613/ | title=Why Comfort Food Comforts | publisher=The Atlantic | date=3 April 2015 | accessdate=21 July 2015 | last=Romm | first = Cari}}</ref> They are believed to be a great coping mechanism for rapidly soothing negative feelings.
==Psychological studies== Consuming energy-dense, high calorie, high in fat or salt, or sweet food; such as ice cream, chocolate or french fries, could trigger the reward system in human's brain, which give a distinctive pleasure or temporarily feeling better.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/science-choice/201609/5-reasons-why-we-crave-comfort-foods|title=5 Reasons Why We Crave Comfort Foods|website=Psychology Today| first = Shahram | last = Heshmat | language=en-US| date = 28 Sep 2016 |access-date=2018-09-05}}</ref> Comfort foods may be consumed to reduce stress and feel better.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Wansink |first1=Brian |first2=Cynthia |last2=Sangerman |title=Engineering comfort foods |journal=American Demographics |date=July 2000 |pages=66–7}}</ref> Regarding the psychological aspects of food addiction that led to the unhealthy eating habits, people often use comfort food to treat themselves. Those with negative emotions tend to eat unhealthy food in an effort to experience the instant gratification which resulted in good feeling — although only short-lived.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://deserthopetreatment.com/addiction-psychology/comfort-food/|title=The Science behind Comfort Food - Desert Hope|work=Desert Hope|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref>
One study divided college-students' comfort-food identifications into four categories (nostalgic foods, indulgence foods, [[convenience food]]s, and physical comfort foods) with a special emphasis on the deliberate selection of particular foods to modify mood or effect, and indications that the medical-therapeutic use of particular foods may ultimately be a matter of mood-alteration.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/07409710500334509 |title=Comfort Foods: An Exploratory Journey into the Social and Emotional Significance of Food |year=2005 |last1=Locher |first1=Julie L. |last2=Yoels |first2=William C. |last3=Maurer |first3=Donna |last4=Van Ells |first4=Jillian |journal=Food and Foodways |volume=13 |issue=4 |pages=273–97}}</ref>
The identification of particular items as comfort food may be idiosyncratic, though patterns are detectable. In one study of American preferences, "males preferred warm, hearty, meal-related comfort foods (such as [[steak]], casseroles, and soup) while females instead preferred comfort foods that were more [[snack]] related (such as chocolate and ice cream). In addition, younger people preferred more snack-related comfort foods compared to those over 55 years of age." The study also revealed strong connections between consumption of comfort foods and feelings of [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0031-9384(03)00203-8 |title=Exploring comfort food preferences across age and gender |year=2003 |last1=Wansink |first1=B |last2=Cheney |first2=M |last3=Chan |first3=N |journal=Physiology & Behavior |volume=79 |issue=4–5 |pages=739–47 |pmid=12954417}}</ref> An article, "The Myth of Comfort Food" asserted that men tend to choose these types of savory comfort foods because they remind them of being "pampered" or spoiled, while women choose snack-related foods because they are associated with low amounts of work and less "cleanup." It also suggested that women are more likely to reach for unhealthier foods in times of stress due to more weight-conscious mindsets.
Comfort food consumption has been seen as a response to [[emotional stress]] and, consequently, as a key contributor to the epidemic of [[obesity in the United States]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1073/pnas.1934666100 |title=Chronic stress and obesity: A new view of 'comfort food' |year=2003 |last1=Dallman |first1=Mary F. |last2=Pecoraro |first2=Norman |last3=Akana |first3=Susan F. |last4=La Fleur |first4=Susanne E. |last5=Gomez |first5=Francisca |last6=Houshyar |first6=Hani |last7=Bell |first7=M. E. |last8=Bhatnagar |first8=Seema|authorlink8=Seema Bhatnagar|last9=Laugero |first9=Kevin D. |last10=Manalo |first10=Sotara |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=100 |issue=20 |pages=11696–701 |pmid=12975524 |jstor=3147854 |pmc=208820}}</ref> The provocation of specific hormonal responses leading selectively to increases in abdominal fat is seen as a form of [[self-medication]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.bbi.2004.11.004 |title=Chronic stress and comfort foods: Self-medication and abdominal obesity |year=2005 |last1=Dallman |first1=Mary F. |last2=Pecoraro |first2=Norman C. |last3=La Fleur |first3=Susanne E. |journal=Brain, Behavior, and Immunity |volume=19 |issue=4 |pages=275–80 |pmid=15944067}}</ref>
Further studies suggest that consumption of comfort food is triggered in men by positive emotions, and by negative ones in women.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.physbeh.2005.08.023 |title=Affect asymmetry and comfort food consumption |year=2005 |last1=Dube |first1=L |last2=Lebel |first2=J |last3=Lu |first3=J |journal=Physiology & Behavior |volume=86 |issue=4 |pages=559–67 |pmid=16209880}}</ref> The stress effect is particularly pronounced among college-aged women, with only 33% reporting [[Healthy diet|healthy eating]] choices during times of emotional stress.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.nutres.2005.11.010 |title=Stress influences appetite and comfort food preferences in college women |year=2006 |last1=Kandiah |first1=Jayanthi |last2=Yake |first2=Melissa |last3=Jones |first3=James |last4=Meyer |first4=Michaela |journal=Nutrition Research |volume=26 |issue=3 |pages=118–23}}</ref> For women specifically, these psychological patterns may be maladaptive.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.physbeh.2008.02.005 |title=Weakened biological signals: Highly-developed eating schemas amongst women are associated with maladaptive patterns of comfort food consumption |year=2008 |last1=Lebel |first1=J |last2=Lu |first2=J |last3=Dube |first3=L |journal=Physiology & Behavior |volume=94 |issue=3 |pages=384–92 |pmid=18325547}}</ref>
A therapeutic use of these findings includes offering comfort foods or "[[happy hour]]" beverages to [[anorexia (symptom)|anorectic]] [[geriatric]] patients whose health and [[quality of life]] otherwise decreases with reduced oral intake.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0197-4572(98)90153-7 |title=Feeding the anorectic client: Comfort foods and happy hour |year=1998 |last1=Wood |first1=Paulette |last2=Vogen |first2=Barbra D |journal=Geriatric Nursing |volume=19 |issue=4 |pages=192–4 |pmid=9866509}}</ref>
==By country== A partial list by country of comfort foods around the world.
===Australia and New Zealand=== {{main|Australian cuisine|New Zealand cuisine}} [[File:Pavlova dessert.JPG|thumb|A [[Pavlova (food)|Pavlova]] garnished with fruit and cream]]

===France=== [[File:Madeleines_de_Commercy.jpg|thumb|A [[madeleine (cake)|madeleine]]. A ''madeleine de Proust'' is a French expression specifically referring to [[Marcel Proust]]'s description of comfort food in ''[[In Search of Lost Time]]''.]] {{main|French cuisine}} {{div col|colwidth=20em}} *[[Crème caramel]] – custard dessert<ref name=Davis-TOC>{{cite book | title = French Comfort Food | first = Hilary | last = Davis | date = 1 August 2014 | publisher = Gibbs Smith | isbn = 978-1423636984 | page = Table of Contents}}</ref> *[[French onion soup]] – onion soup with cheese and bread<ref name=Davis-TOC /> *[[Gratin dauphinois]] – potato slices baked with cream <ref name=msn33 /> *[[Nutella]] – sweet [[Spread (food)|spread]] of [[Cocoa solids|cocoa]] and [[hazelnut]]s <ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.thelocal.fr/20180126/what-the-great-nutella-riots-of-2018-tell-us-about-the-french | title = What the 'great Nutella riots' of 2018 tell us about the French | work = The Local fr | publisher = The Local Europe AB | date= 26 January 2018 | accessdate = 30 January 2018 | quote = France's love affair with the Italian chocolate hazelnut spread Nutella is well-known.... In fact, according to some figures 26 percent of the world consumption of Nutella is done by the French even though the brand is Italian. This means that around a whopping 75,000 tonnes of Nutella are consumed every year in France. France's long love affair with the chocolate spread starts, for many, at childhood when it is the sweet and some say sickly breakfast of choice for many French school children. And according to Paris food writer and author of the blog Chocolate & Zucchini [[Clotilde Dusoulier]] it could be this childhood link which is partly behind the France's love for Nutella. "French people eat it by the spoonful. I had it on toast for breakfast as a child," Dusoulier told The Local. "And like with candy, grownups continue to eat it to connect with their inner child." The food writer also explained that the French have a tendency to turn to sweets in times of uncertainty.}}</ref> *[[Pâté]] – cold meat paste<ref name=Davis-TOC /> *[[Pot-au-feu]] – beef stew<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.foodandwine.com/comfort-food/pot-au-feu-ultimate-french-comfort-food | title = Pot-au-Feu: The Ultimate French Comfort Food | first = Hannah | last = Walhout | date = 22 March 2017 | work = [[Food & Wine]] | access-date = 30 January 2018}}</ref> {{div col end}}
===Indonesia=== {{main|Indonesian cuisine}} [[File:Bubur ayam chicken porridge.JPG|thumb|[[Bubur ayam]] (chicken [[congee]]) is an [[Indonesian cuisine|Indonesian]] comfort food.]] Some popular [[Indonesian cuisine|Indonesian foods]] are considered to be comfort food, usually served hot or warm, and soupy or with a soft texture. Most of them are high in [[carbohydrate|carbs]] or fat, such as fried rice, congee, and noodles which are high in carbs; while meatballs and grilled skewered meats contains fair amount of fat and salt. Comfort foods often are the kind of food that provides nostalgic sentiments, as they often called ''masakan rumahan'' (home cooking) or ''masakan ibu'' (mother's dishes). In Indonesia, the warm and soft texture of [[bubur ayam]] is believed to help people to recover during [[convalescence]].<ref name="detikFood">{{cite web | title=Comfort Food, Makanan Yang Bikin Nyaman dan Kangen | publisher=Detik Food | author=Fitria Rahmadianti | date=26 September 2012 | url=http://food.detik.com/read/2012/09/26/093841/2036688/297/2/comfort-food-makanan-yang-bikin-nyaman-dan-kangen | language=Indonesian | accessdate=2 September 2014 }}</ref> Sayur sop or sup ayam is Indonesian chicken soup that often sought during [[influenza|flu]]. The warm soup contains chunk of chicken, bits of potato, carrot, and common [[green bean]] served in chicken stock.<ref name="CNN-Indo-sup ayam">{{cite news | title = Alasan Sup Ayam Jadi Makanan Paling Dicari Saat Flu | author = Christina Andhika Setyanti | work = CNN Indonesia | date = 13 November 2015 | url = http://www.cnnindonesia.com/gaya-hidup/20151113133925-262-91459/alasan-sup-ayam-jadi-makanan-paling-dicari-saat-flu/ | language = Indonesian}}</ref>
Some Indonesian comfort foods are traditional Indonesian food and some are derived from [[Chinese Indonesian cuisine|Chinese influences]]. For some Indonesians, especially those who are abroad, comfort food might also be a certain brand or type of Indonesian [[instant noodle]], such as [[Indomie Mi goreng]].<ref name="Indomie - Mi Goreng">{{cite web | url = http://en.petitchef.com/recipes/indomie-mi-goreng-fid-997251 | title = Maggi goreng mamak | author = nava-k | work = Petitchef | date = | access-date = 31 October 2017}}</ref> Indonesian comfort foods include: {{div col|colwidth=20em}} *[[Bakmi]] or [[mie ayam]] – noodles (''mi'') with pork (''bak'') or chicken (''ayam'') <ref>{{cite web|url=http://indonesiaeats.com/my-comfort-food-mie-jamur-pangsit-bakso/|title=My Comfort Food – Mie Jamur Pangsit Bakso | date = 8 August 2007 | work = Indonesia Eats | publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2015}}</ref> *[[Bakso]] – meatball soup <ref name="detikFood"/><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/home/comfort-food-helps-indonesian-maid-recover/407204 | title = {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Cortical deafness | image = brodmann_41_42.png | caption = Location of the primary auditory cortex in the brain | | pronounce = | field = | synonyms = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Cortical deafness''' is a rare form of [[sensorineural hearing loss]] caused by damage to the [[primary auditory cortex]]. Cortical deafness is an auditory disorder where the patient is unable to hear sounds but has no apparent damage to the anatomy of the ear (see [[auditory system]]), which can be thought of as the combination of [[auditory verbal agnosia]] and [[auditory agnosia]]. Patients with cortical deafness cannot hear any sounds, that is, they are not aware of sounds including non-speech, voices, and speech sounds.<ref name="Ingram, 2007">{{cite book |author=Ingram, John Henry |title=Neurolinguistics: an introduction to spoken language processing and its disorders |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge, UK |year=2007 |pages=160–171 |isbn=0-521-79190-1 |oclc=297335127 |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> Although patients appear and feel completely deaf, they can still exhibit some reflex responses such as turning their head towards a loud sound.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Stroke Syndromes|last = Bogousslavsky|first = Julien|publisher = Cambridge UP|year = 2001|isbn = |location = Cambridge|pages = 153}}</ref> ==Cause== Cortical deafness is caused by bilateral cortical lesions in the [[Auditory cortex|primary auditory cortex]] located in the [[temporal lobe]]<nowiki/>s of the brain.<ref name="Graham, 1980">{{cite journal |vauthors=Graham J, Greenwood R, Lecky B |title=Cortical deafness—a case report and review of the literature |journal=J. Neurol. Sci. |volume=48 |issue=1 |pages=35–49 |date=October 1980 |pmid=7420124 |doi=10.1016/0022-510X(80)90148-3 |url=}}</ref> The ascending auditory pathways are damaged, causing a loss of perception of sound. Inner ear functions, however, remains intact. Cortical deafness is most often cause by [[stroke]], but can also result from brain injury or birth defects.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.audiology.org/sites/default/files/journal/JAAA_05_05_08.pdf|title = Cortical Deafness: A longitudinal study|last = Hood|first = Linda|date = 1999|journal = The American Journal of Nursing|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> More specifically, a common cause is bilateral embolic stroke to the area of Heschl's gyri.<ref>citation needed</ref> Cortical deafness is extremely rare, with only twelve reported cases. Each case has a distinct context and different rates of recovery.
It is thought that cortical deafness could be a part of a spectrum of an overall cortical hearing disorder.<ref name="Graham, 1980" /> In some cases, patients with cortical deafness have had recovery of some hearing function, resulting in partial auditory deficits such as auditory verbal agnosia.<ref name="Graham, 1980" /><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cavinato M, Rigon J, Volpato C, Semenza C, Piccione F |title=Preservation of auditory P300-like potentials in cortical deafness |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=e29909 |year=2012 |pmid=22272260 |pmc=3260175 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0029909 |url=}}</ref> This syndrome might be difficult to distinguish from a bilateral temporal lesion such as described above.
== Diagnosis == Since cortical deafness and auditory [[agnosia]] have many similarities, diagnosing the disorder proves to be difficult. Bilateral lesions near the primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe are important criteria. Cortical deafness requires demonstration that [[brainstem]] auditory responses are normal, but cortical evoked potentials are impaired. [[Brainstem auditory evoked potential]]s ('''BAEP)''', also referred to as brainstem auditory evoked responses ('''BAER''') show the neuronal activity in the auditory nerve, cochlear nucleus, superior olive, and inferior colliculus of the brainstem. They typically have a response latency of no more than six milliseconds with an amplitude of approximately one microvolt. The latency of the responses gives critical information: if cortical deafness is applicable, '''LLR''' (long-latency responses) are completely abolished and '''MLR''' (middle latency responses) are either abolished or significantly impaired.<ref name=":0" /> In auditory agnosia, LLRs and MLRs are preserved.
Another important aspect of cortical deafness that is often overlooked is that patients ''feel'' deaf. They are aware of their inability to hear environmental sounds, non-speech and speech sounds. Patients with [[auditory agnosia]] can be unaware of their deficit, and insist that they are not deaf.<ref>Denes, G., and Luigi Pizzamiglio. "Comprehension Disorders." Handbook of Clinical and Experimental Neuropsychology. Hove, East Sussex, UK: Psychology, 1999. 210. Print.</ref> Verbal deafness and auditory agnosia are disorders of a selective, perceptive and associative nature whereas cortical deafness relies on the anatomic and functional disconnection of the auditory cortex from acoustic impulses.
=== Case examples === Although cortical deafness has very specific parameters of diagnosis, its causes on the other hand can vary tremendously. The following are three case studies with different reasons for cortical deafness. # A case published in 2001 describes the patient as 20-year-old man referred for cochlear implants because of bilateral deafness following a motorcycle accident two years earlier.<ref name=":0" /> His [[CT scan|CT]] shows hemorrhagic lesions involving both [[internal capsule]]s. He was comatose for several weeks and awoke quadriparetic, cognitively impaired and completely deaf. He exhibited a response towards the occasional sudden, loud sound, however, by turning his head. Reading and writing capabilities were maintained, and he was able to communicate by lip-reading. His own speech was dysarthric, but comprehensible. Normal tympanograms and stapedial reflexes imply that the middle and [[inner ear]] remained functioning and the auditory nerve was intact. His auditory nerve was tested by evoking responses with normal auditory nerve potentials at 10 dB bilaterally. The results of the BAER waves were normal, but an abnormal complex IV-V suggested that the pathways were functioning through the brainstem, but there was a lesion present in the mid-brain. With these findings, it was determined the patient had cortical deafness due to bilateral interruption of the ascending auditory pathway associated with hemorrhagic lesions of both internal capsules. Therefore, cochlear implantation was not performed.<ref name=":0" /> # Published in 1994, this patient was monitored over the course of almost 20 years after exhibiting signs of hearing impairment as an infant.<ref name=":1" /> Audiologic and related test results in concurrence with MRI confirmed bilateral absence of considerable portions of her temporal lobes resulting in cortical deafness. Although physiologic measures demonstrate normal peripheral hearing sensitivity, this patient's speech has the inflection and prosodic characteristics associated with profound peripheral hearing loss, and she is unable to understand spoken communication. Behaviorally obtained pure-tone thresholds were variable, ranging from normal to moderate hearing loss with normal middle ear muscle reflexes and normal ABRs to high- and low-intensity stimuli. Auditory middle latency and cortical evoked potentials were grossly abnormal, consistent with the central nature of cortical deafness. Because of her inability to communicate auditorily, this patient was ultimately taught American Sign Language and educated at the Louisiana School for the Deaf. At the completion of the case study, the patient was married and expecting a child.<ref name=":1" /> # A more recent study, published in 2013 the patient described is a 56-year-old woman a history of [[hypertension]], [[hypercholesterolemia]], and multiple cerebrovascular accident (CVA) who presented in March 2009 with a complaint of complete bilateral hearing loss. In March 2009, she experienced an acute right-sided insulotemporal intracerebral hemorrhage. Immediately after this event, the patient complained of hearing loss with the inability to hear all sounds except for severe bilateral [[tinnitus]]. Imaging revealed [[sequela]]e in the left cerebral cortex from her previous CVA. The new right-sided hemorrhage was centered on the posterior putamen with surrounding [[edema]] involving the posterior portion of the posterior limbs of the internal, external, and extreme capsules. Signal abnormalities extended into the right temporal lobe. The patient had no other neurologic deficits and spoke fluently, although with poor internal volume control of her voice. Otoscopic examination revealed normal-appearing external auditory canals, intact tympanic membranes bilaterally, and normal middle ear anatomy. Audiogram at that time showed bilateral profound hearing loss with no responses to pure-tone or speech testing.
== Treatment == Auditory perception can improve with time.There seems to be a level of neuroplasticity that allows patients to recover the ability to perceive environmental and certain musical sounds.<ref name=":2" /> Patients presenting with cortical hearing loss and no other associated symptoms recover to a variable degree, depending on the size and type of the cerebral lesion. Patients whose symptoms include both motor deficits and aphasias often have larger lesions with an associated poorer prognosis in regard to functional status and recovery.<ref name=":2" />
Cochlear or auditory brainstem implantation could also be treatment options. Electrical stimulation of the peripheral auditory system may result in improved sound perception or cortical remapping in patients with cortical deafness.<ref name="Graham, 1980" /> However, hearing aids are an inappropriate answer for cases like these. Any auditory signal, regardless if has been amplified to normal or high intensities, is useless to a system unable to complete its processing.<ref name=":1" /> Ideally, patients should be directed toward resources to aid them in lip-reading, learning American Sign Language, as well as speech and occupational therapy. Patients should follow-up regularly to evaluate for any long-term recovery.<ref name=":2" /> == History == Early reports, published in the late 19th century, describe patients with acute onset of deafness after experiencing symptoms described as [[apoplexy]]. The only means of definitive diagnosis in these reports were postmortem dissections.<ref name=":2">Brody, Robert M., Brian D. Nicholas, Michael J. Wolf, Paula B. Marcinkevich, and Gregory J. Artz. "Cortical Deafness: A Case Report and Review of the Literature." Otology and Neurology 34.7 (2013): 1226–229. Ovid. Web.</ref> Subsequent cases throughout the 20th century reflect advancements in diagnoses of both hearing loss and stroke. With the advent of audiometric and [[Electrophysiology|electrophysiologic]] studies, investigators could diagnose cortical deafness with increasing precision. Advances in imaging techniques, such as [[Magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]], greatly improved the diagnosis and localization of cerebral infarcts that coincide with primary or secondary auditory centers.<ref name=":2" /> Neurological and cognitive testing help to distinguish between total cortical deafness and [[auditory agnosia]], resulting in the inability to perceive words, music, or specific environmental sounds.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite journal | vauthors = Hood L, Berlin C, Allen P | title = Cortical deafness: a longitudinal study. | journal = J Am Acad Audiol | volume = 5 | issue = 5 | pages = 330–42 | year = 1994 | pmid = 7987023}} == External links == {{Medical resources | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = D006313 }}
<!-- Navigation boxes below --> {{Diseases of the ear and mastoid process}} {{Lesions of spinal cord and brain}}
<!-- Categories below -->

page.title: Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons

revision.text:
The '''Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons''' was a declaration of the [[United Nations General Assembly|General Assembly]] of the [[United Nations]], made on 9 December 1975. It is the 3447th resolution made by the Assembly.
As a resolution of the Assembly, it is not binding on member nations, but it forms a framework that may be drawn on for the purposes of international and domestic law.
It consists of a lengthy preamble, and thirteen proclamations that broadly promote the rights of those with disabilities.
In 2007 the [[Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities]] was adopted.<ref>https://www.un.org/disabilities/convention/conventionfull.shtml Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities</ref>
==Proclamations== The Declaration makes thirteen distinct proclamations:
# Definition of the term "disabled person" as "''any person unable to ensure by himself or herself, wholly or partly, the necessities of a normal individual and/or social life, as a result of deficiency, either congenital or not, in his or her physical or mental capabilities''". # # Assertion that these rights apply to all disabled persons "''without any exception whatsoever and without distinction or discrimination on the basis of race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinions, national or social origin, state of wealth, birth or any other situation applying either to the disabled person himself or herself or to his or her family''". # # Right to respect for [[human dignity]]. # # Right to same civil and political rights as other human beings. # # Right to measures designed to enable [[Self-sufficiency|self-reliance]]. # # Right to medical, psychological and functional treatment as necessary. # # Right to economic and social security, including the right to [[equal opportunity|employment]]. # # Right to have consideration of special needs at all stages of economic and social planning. # # Right to live with their families or with foster parents and to participate in all social, creative or recreational activities. # # Right to protection against exploitation, discrimination, and abuse. # # Right to qualified legal aid. # # Right to consult [[List of disability rights organizations|organizations of disabled persons]] for in matters of concern. # # Right to be fully informed of the rights proclaimed in the Declaration.<ref>http://www.ohchr.org/EN/ProfessionalInterest/Pages/RightsOfDisabledPersons.aspx Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons (U.N. General Assembly - 30th Session. 1975.)</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * [https://www.un.org/development/desa/disabilities/the-united-nations-and-persons-with-disabilities-chronology-1945-1980.html The United Nations and Persons with Disabilities Chronology, 1945 - 1980] * [https://www.un.org/development/desa/disabilities/about-us/history-of-disability-and-the-united-nations/the-united-nations-and-persons-with-disabilities-chronology-1980s-present.html The United Nations and Persons with Disabilities Chronology: 1980’s – present]
[[Category:Disability rights]] [[Category:United Nations General Assembly resolutions]] [[Category:1975 in law]] [[Category:1975 in international relations]]
